title: A Proposal of Modular Multilevel Converter Using a Three-winding Transformer
abstract: This paper proposes a new type of Modular Multilevel Converter (MMC) using a three-winding transformer. In general, MMCs require a buffer reactor in each arm, which increases the number of components required in the converter and the converter footprint. The proposed MMC with a three-winding transformer does not require buffer reactors. The mathematical representation of the proposed converter was first described. The operational performance of the proposed MMC was found to be identical to the typical MMC (with the buffer reactor topology) by making comparisons in the experimental tests on two physical prototype converters rated at 10kVA.

This paper proposes a new type of Modular Multilevel Converter (MMC) using a three-winding transformer. In gen-
eral, MMCs require a buﬀer reactor in each arm, which increases the number of components required in the converter
and the converter footprint. The proposed MMC with a three-winding transformer does not require buﬀer reactors. The
mathematical representation of the proposed converter was ﬁrst described. The operational performance of the pro-
posed MMC was found to be identical to the typical MMC (with the bu ﬀer reactor topology) by making comparisons
in the experimental tests on two physical prototype converters rated at 10 kV A.
Keywords: modular multilevel converter, high voltage direct current transmission, Flexible AC Transmission Systems (FACTS)
1. Introduction
Recently, Modular Multilevel Converter (MMC) has been
studied (1)–(8). MMC consists of series connected half bridge
converters, so it enables voltage level and power ratings ad-
justable. MMC can generate approximated sine wave out-
put at AC terminal with reduced switching frequency of in-
dividual power device. Moreover it does not require AC
ﬁlters if the number of levels is adequate. As MMC has
these advantages, researches are advancing to high voltage
applications such as high voltage direct current transmission
(HVDC)
(9) (10), and it has been already operated in actual trans-
mission systems (11) (12).
The reactors used in the typical MMC are of air core type,
just like those used in the grid connected devices such as
SVC (TCR) (13). This type of reactors has a very simple con-
ﬁguration so it can achieve low cost and remove the risk of
magnetic saturation. However, the air core reactor requires a
wide clearance space in order to avoid electromagnetic inter-
ference. In this paper, a new type MMC which does not re-
quire the buﬀer reactors in principle was proposed. As most
of grid connected power electronic devices such as HVDC
and FACTS require a transformer to obtain the optimal volt-
age for power electronic switching devices to operate. By
applying the three winding transformer, it is possible to elim-
inates the buﬀer reactors, as the result, reduce the converter
footprint and the number of components of the converter. In
this paper, the equations of voltage and current relationship

2. Modular Multilevel Converter with Three
Winding Transformer
2.1 Proposed Converter Topology A circuit dia-
gram of the proposed converter topology is shown in Fig. 1.
Three winding transformers are used within the cascaded half
bridge MMC. There are three three-winding transformers for
three phase AC circuit. The primary windings of the trans-
formers are connected to AC grid. Secondary and tertiary
windings are connected to converter upper arm and lower arm
in each leg. These three windings are wrapped around a com-
mon iron core. The secondary winding and the tertiary wind-
ing are wound in inverse direction, and the negative sides of
each winding are connected each other. A connected point of
secondary and tertiary winding is center of each leg, which
becomes neutral point of the converter.
In MMC, a current in each arm contains two components,
namely the common component and the di ﬀerential compo-
nent, between upper and lower arm
(3)–(5). The common current
component ﬂows through both secondary and tertiary wind-
ings while the di ﬀerential current component ﬂows through
only one winding, secondary or tertiary. Figure 2 shows mag-
netomotive force due to the currents in secondary winding
and tertiary winding in these two cases. In common current
component case, the direction of the magnetomotive force at
the secondary winding and the tertiary winding are in oppo-
site direction and therefore they are cancelled out each other.
The total magnetic ﬂux generated by the common current
component does not exist in the common iron core. In dif-
ferential current component case, the magnetomotive force
of each winding is in the same direction, so they are added to

As well known, transformer has leakage inductance. The

Moreover, it is possible to connect all the midpoints of
the transformer to form a neutral point at the converter side.
When this transformer neutral point is used as the neutral
point of the DC link, this topology constitutes a symmetrical
monopole in the applications like HVDC transmission sys-
tem. When it is not connected to the ground, it constitutes an
asymmetrical monopole or bi-pole HVDC transmission sys-
tem.

3. Experimental Results
Two prototype converters are connected to the same AC
power supply point at the AC side and they are connected
through a DC line at DC side, like back-to-back connection.
The parameters of the proposed prototype MMC are shown
in Table 2.
The transformer used in the experimentation is shown in
Fig. 8. It is a normal single phase three winding transformer;
its iron core has saturation magnetic density which is 1.85 [T]
at 116% (233 V , 50 Hz) of rated voltage level. In rated voltage
(200 V 50 Hz), the magnetic density of iron core is 1.59 [T].
Figure 10 shows experimental results in grid connected op-
eration. In all results, good sinusoidal waveforms at AC line
current are obtained and the capacitor voltages of each cell
are balanced each other. When converter and inverter op-
eration (Figs. 10 (a), (b)), the converter arm current has dc
component. However, the three winding transformer does
not occur magnetic saturation in both power ﬂow direction.
When they were operated in reactive power mode as shown
in Figs. 10(c), (d), the results are the same.
Figure 11 shows experimental results in reversing power
ﬂow operation by back to back converter connection. The
behavior of converter is stable even in during power ﬂow di-
rection changing.
Figure 12 shows experimental results in fault ride through
operation at AC line fault. A magnetic saturation does not
appear even when AC line voltage is suddenly changing. As
these results, the proposed MMC with three winding trans-
former operates as same as typical MMC with bu ﬀer reac-
tors. Furthermore, it does not adversely a ﬀect the DC bias
magnetism at the transformer to merge bu ﬀer reactor into a
grid connected transformer.

In this experiment, three single phase three-winding trans-
formers are applied. However, it can also use three phase
three winding transformer which has three-leg iron core or
ﬁve-leg iron core. When the three phase transformer is used,
the primary winding and the secondary winding and the ter-
tiary winding should be wounded to the same leg for each
phase, and a magnetomotive force by common current com-
ponent should be cancelled like a single phase three winding
transformer.
4. Conclusions
A new type of Modular Multilevel Converter using a three
winding transformer was proposed in this paper. The pro-
posed circuitry merges the bu ﬀer reactors into converter
transformer, so as to save the space and components of con-
verter. Since DC ﬂux is cancelled on the same core within
the three winding transformer, it does not adversely aﬀect the
DC bias magnetism at the transformer, and therefore, the pro-
posed MMC with three winding transformer does not require
any special duty for magnetic density to the transformer
The experiment conducted on physical 10 kV A prototype
converters shows that the proposed converter had the same
